text:
One day we ran out of disk space. 

            total       used       free     shared    buffers     cached
Mem:        969836     948408      21428          0     171052     425256
-/+ buffers/cache:     352100     617736
Swap:      1966072          0    1966072

cleaned it up and now have over 100 gigs of space. what happs now is when I start httpd -X -k start, it 
runs with a pid of:

root      9502  0.7  0.8  21668  7804 pts/2    S+   11:12   0:00 /usr/sbin/httpd

after a few minutes, it dissappers. No errors in the log files, no nothing.

nothing in the ssl_error_log either.

I tried bug #40408, no effect at all.
however, this problem is just like bug 16981.

Need to know from you guys is there a way to trap all information as to what the command is 
proccessing and where it times out at.

here are some clips of httpd.conf: - not all of it.

___________> above are tried from bug #36979 - NO EFFECT!<________________

however, I can connect to port 8080 which has JBOSS there. but when ever I use port 80, or the straight 
IP address,it sits there waiting for something. 

This server is a standalone that has no FQDN, just IP:24.227.60.28:80 used is for program D to be used 
as an INLINE HTML page to another webserver.

http://httpd.apache.org/dev/debugging.html#backtrace

for obtaining further information. What happens if you just start it with
apachectl the normal way? Does it work?

text:
(In reply to comment #2)
> just start it with apachectl the normal way, yes, same result.
> 
> Followed http://httpd.apache.org/dev/debugging.html#backtrace
> http://httpd.apache.org/dev/debugging.html#truss
> 
> No luck there, blank files.

What do you mean with blank files? For sure debugging the server does not change
the output of the error log (unless you change the loglevel during this).
Using strace or gdb should give us an idea why httpd disappears.
BTW: Increasing the LogLevel to debug is also a good idea.

text:
Please do the following:

gdb /usr/sbin/httpd
run -X -d /etc/httpd -E /tmp/error.log

Do NOT set a breakpoint. If httpd crashes the gdb prompt will return and you can
do a 

thread apply all bt full

to let us know where the crash happened.
If it just exits 'normally' (gdb prompt also returns in this case) then there
should be either something in the error log (especially when loglevel is set to
debug, which you should do) and/or in /tmp/error.log. Please let me know the
contents of /tmp/error.log.

System did not exit normally, Did not crash, did not return. Nothing in the logfile.

text:
Created attachment 19373
possible error log for gdb

creator: medwayis@yahoo.com

text:
Sorry for being confused, but if gdb does NOT return it does mean that httpd
does not crash or exit. This is contrary to your initial report where you said
that httpd disappears after a few minutes. So it seems to work. This means that
I currently cannot help you any further.

Two further remarks:

1. The command
   thread apply all bt full
   must be entered in the same gdb session in which httpd runs.

2. Please do not attach rtf files. They are hard to read, examine and analyse.  
   Please only attach plain text files or in the rare case that a screenshot is 
   needed gif or jpeg images. If you have a lot of files feel free to put them 
   into a zip or tar.gz archive and attach this.
creator: rpluem@apache.org

so it'is still broken. HTTPD is supposed to run as indicated in ps -aux, but never releases the command 
line to continue running.

a proper start of httpd should return "[  OK  ]"

sample --  [root@terasembot httpd]#httpd                              [   OK   ]

but does not, it does this:

[root@terasembot httpd]#httpd

wait a few minutes later.
you get this

[root@terasembot httpd]#

and thats it.

I did get a strace on HTTPD. that might the only one command I can think of that will enable me to 
create a log file.


do you want to strace file?
creator: medwayis@yahoo.com
covener@gmail.com
text: We won't be able to piece together what's going on in your system where the files may have been corrupted.  An strace at the time may have been helpful, but it's been many years since this was marked NEEDINFO.
